subject: joining_western_archive
key_passage: Uncle, I have taken a position at the Western Archive. The work of Tessery Vold draws me here—his Passage Diagrams speak to something I cannot yet name.

subject: encouragement
key_passage: Nephew, I am pleased you follow structure rather than position. Vold understood that relations precede objects. Find what he left unfinished.

subject: coherent_shifts_discovery
key_passage: I have found Vold's late manuscript—'On the Coherence of Shifts.' He sensed something about transformations but never formalized it. What makes a shift coherent?

subject: constellation_analogy
key_passage: In my constellation work, coherence means the pattern is preserved though individual stars may shift. Perhaps your shifts must similarly preserve some global structure?

subject: naturality_proposal
key_passage: I have it. A transformation is coherent if it commutes with structure. For every morphism f, the naturality square must close. This is the condition Vold sought.

subject: document_functors_connection
key_passage: Director Dray, I have read your work on document functors. I believe my natural transformations provide the language for coherent shifts between your representation schemes.

subject: initial_response
key_passage: Tross, your proposal intrigues me. But how does naturality apply when the functors assign sets rather than numerical values? Show me an example with actual archive documents.

subject: archive_example
key_passage: Consider these two documents from our boundary surveys. Apply the subject-catalog functor and the author-index functor. The transformation between them is natural—see how the classification diagram commutes.

subject: acceptance
key_passage: I see it now. Your naturality squares capture exactly what I meant by 'coherent classification.' We must collaborate on this.

subject: weighted_transformations
key_passage: Colleague Vance, how do natural transformations interact with your weighted passages? When we add weights, does naturality still hold?

subject: weights_and_naturality
key_passage: The forgetful functor from weighted to unweighted passages is natural. Adding unit weights is also natural. But arbitrary reweighting is not—the naturality square fails.

subject: uncle_acknowledgment
key_passage: Uncle, in my treatise I acknowledge your constellation analogy. Your insight that 'pattern preservation through local change' was the key. The naturality square formalizes this.

subject: naturality_conditions_debate
key_passage: Tross, I have found cases where transformations that seem natural fail upon closer inspection. The nonlinear embedding shifts break your squares. How do you account for this?

subject: linearity_requirement
key_passage: Dray, you have identified the boundary. Natural transformations require structure preservation. Nonlinear maps do not preserve the categorical framework. This is a feature, not a bug—naturality tests whether a shift is truly coherent.

subject: synthesis_agreement
key_passage: I accept your position. Naturality is a test, not a guarantee. Some transformations fail the test, and this failure is informative. Let us publish our correspondence as a dialogue.

subject: definitive_work_completion
key_passage: Director Dray, I have completed 'The Naturality Principle.' It synthesizes our decade of correspondence. Your document functors and my natural transformations are now unified.

subject: congratulations
key_passage: Tross, your work will outlast us both. You have given us the language to speak of coherent change. The naturality square is now as fundamental as the morphism itself.
